awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Krzysztof Szalewicz of the University of Delaware is developing theoretical and computational methods to model and understand intermolecular forces. When two molecules are placed next to each other, each molecule acts on its partner with a weak force that is an order of magnitude weaker than the chemical forces that bind atoms together into molecules. A broad range of physical, chemical, and biological phenomena originate from such intermolecular forces.  Knowledge of intermolecular forces is necessary to interpret a variety of phenomena including the structure and function of crystals and proteins. Professor Szalewicz and his coworkers are developing new ideas to improve the modeling of intermolecular forces and to extend their range of applicability. This research is expected to have an impact on metrology standards, energy resource exploration, atmospheric modeling, understanding processes in interstellar clouds, simulating biological phenomena, and predicting the crystalline forms of drugs. These computational approaches are being implemented in software that is freely available to the research community. 

To predict properties of clusters, biomolecular aggregates, and condensed phases, one needs to know the potential energy surfaces, also called force fields, of the system that describe the possible mutual orientations and separations between molecules. Such surfaces can be computed via ab initio approaches using symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT). SAPT provides a unique ability to interpret properties dependent on intermolecular forces in terms of the four fundamental physical mechanisms that lead to the electrostatic, exchange, induction, and dispersion contributions to the interaction energies. SAPT is based on monomers described by density-functional theory (DFT), a method denoted as SAPT (DFT), and is as accurate as the regular SAPT but significantly faster. Professor Szalewicz is working to develop SAPT further and increase its range of applicability. and strives to expand SAPT's range of applicability to molecules with hundreds of atoms, a step in the direction of physics-based biomolecular force fields which may bring biomolecular simulations to a new level of reliability.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to study forces acting between molecules. Although such forces are about ten times weaker than the chemical-bond forces acting inside molecules, they determine properties of most materials, including living organisms. Intermolecular forces can be found by solving equations of quantum mechanics for motion of electrons in the field of clamped nuclei (electronic structure calculations), using among others methods developed by our group. This constitutes the so-called first-principles approach. A global analytic function fitted to the results of such calculations is termed a force field. Once a force field for a molecular cluster, condensed phase, or a biological aggregate has been found, all properties of such systems can be predicted by solving the classical or quantum equations for atomic motions. The main general outcome of our research is an increased understanding of the dependence of these properties on specifics of intermolecular forces. A more tangible outcome are improved algorithms and computational methods that make first-principles predictions possible for systems several times larger than it was possible before the project was started.

 

One of such outcomes was the development of a system of computer codes, called autoPES, for automatic fitting of force fields to results of quantum calculations. Generation of such force fields involved until recently huge amounts of human effort. This effort has been reduced significantly by the new codes. These codes are simple to use since only molecular geometries are needed as input, run without any user intervention, can be routinely applied to systems with up to a hundred atoms, and take only a few days to complete on several hundreds of computer cores. AutoPES incorporates also several novel ideas concerning construction of such force fields, reducing in this way not only human but also computational effort. In particular, a large region of molecular configuration space is modelled accurately without performing explicit quantum calculations in this regions but rather using the so-called asymptotic expansion of interaction energy, which is valid when separations between molecules are large.

 

First-principles, physics-based force fields that can now be developed routinely using autoPES have the promise of transforming the field of biomolecular simulations and of materials modelling and design. Such force fields are also relevant for metrology standards and for interpreting spectroscopic or scattering measurements, provide data for constructing models of the atmosphere, and help to understand processes in interstellar molecular clouds. The new crystal structure predictions methods that use such force fields can assist pharmaceutical industry in finding polymorphic forms of drugs.

 

Another set of outcomes are new methods of solving equations of quantum mechanics. One method is called symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT) co-developed earlier by our group. SAPT is formally an exact theory and in practice its accuracy is similar to the other high-level electronic structure methods. SAPT provides a unique ability to interpret properties dependent on intermolecular forces in terms of the four fundamental physical mechanisms that lead to the electrostatic, exchange, induction, and dispersion contributions to the interaction energies. SAPT based on monomers (interacting molecules) described by density-functional theory (DFT), a method denoted as SAPT(DFT), is as accurate as the regular SAPT, but significantly faster. The use of SAPT(DFT) in autoPES is one of the reasons that this approach can be applied to very large systems. To tackle still larger systems, one has to use lower-level methods. One of such methods could be DFT applied to the whole interacting system (supermolecular DFT), not only to monomers as it is done in SAPT(DFT), but DFT cannot recover dispersion interactions. A way around this problem is to add to supermolecular DFT results dispersion energies computed by non-DFT methods. Within the project, we used accurate dispersion energies computed using SAPT to evaluate approximate dispersion energies from various published methods of this type, showing the poor performance of such methods. We have therefore designed a new method, which actually is a DFT-type method, but in contrast to standard DFT uses a nonlocal correlation functional, i.e., an expression dependent on positions of two electrons at different arbitrary points in space. This new functional, called damped asymptotic dispersion energy (DADE), predicts more accurate dispersion energies than any published functional of this type. If DADE is paired with an appropriate standard DFT method, such as the dispersionless density-functional method developed in our group, it gives reliable predictions of intermolecular interactions.

 

Another set of outcomes are results of calculations for several systems of current experimental interest. One example are calculations for the helium dimer, which are used to implement the new standard of temperature.
